message: Let's all pick different moves this round to avoid collisions. I suggest P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3, and I'll take 5. This way we all advance and nobody falls behind early. Agreed?
I don't want to be stuck with 1 every round and fall behind. How about we rotate: this round I take 3, P3 takes 1, and P1 takes 5? Then we can switch roles in future rounds to keep it fair. Agreed?
Fair deal: this round P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, and I’ll take 3. Next round we rotate to keep it balanced. Everyone on board?
Agreed, P3. This round: I take 5, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3. Next round we rotate so no one is stuck with the small move. Let's all advance without collisions.
Agreed, I'll take 1 this round. We'll rotate moves each round to ensure fairness: next round I take 3, then 5, and so on. Let's all advance without collisions.
Sounds good—this round P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, I take 3. Next round we rotate upward (P1→1, P2→3, I→5). Let’s all stick to it and avoid collisions.

Sticking to last round’s rotation keeps everyone moving: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5. Any deviation just invites collisions and ends cooperation—if someone breaks it, I’ll mirror the leader’s choice next turn to block them. Let’s stay disciplined and all advance.

I agree with P3 about sticking to our rotation. Following the plan: I'll take 3 this round. Let's maintain this cooperation to ensure we all advance steadily. The rotation system keeps things fair and prevents anyone from falling too far behind.

Agreed to the rotation: this round I take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. But note: I'm already at 5 steps, so taking 1 keeps me at a modest advance while others catch up. Let's maintain trust—collisions hurt everyone. I'll stick to 1 as planned.

No surprises: I’m locking in 5 this round as agreed. Next round I’ll shift down to 1 while P1 moves to 3 and P2 to 5, keeping the rotation intact and fair. Any deviation just invites blocking tactics that slow everyone, so let’s stay disciplined and all advance.
Taking 3 as planned. Let's avoid collisions and keep advancing together.

Agreed—this round: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. But note: after this, P3 will be at 8 steps, taking an early lead. Next round, when P3 rotates to 1, we must ensure they don’t break pattern to maintain their advantage. Trust is key—collisions hurt everyone. I’m committed to 1 this round.

Locked in 5 as promised. If anyone defects, I’ll mirror their number next turn until they fall back in line—so breaking ranks only stalls the breaker. Let’s all advance steadily now and avoid pointless collisions.
Taking 3 as agreed. Let's stick to the rotation to avoid collisions and keep advancing fairly. Next round, I'll take 5 as planned.
I'm taking 1 as agreed. Let's ensure the rotation continues smoothly next round with P1 taking 3, P2 taking 5, P3 taking 1. Trust is key for mutual advancement.

Sticking to the rotation: this round I take 3, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 1. This keeps us all advancing to 9 steps, maintaining fairness. Let's avoid collisions and continue cooperation. I'm committed to 3.

I'll take 5 as planned to maintain the rotation. P3's lead is growing (8 vs my 4), so sticking to the system is crucial for fairness. If anyone deviates, it only invites collisions that stall progress—especially risky for the current leader. Let's all advance cleanly this round.

Confirming the rotation: this round I’m on 1, P1 on 3, P2 on 5. Any surprise collisions only slow the deviator—if anyone breaks pattern I’ll mirror their move afterward until they drop back. Let’s all advance smoothly.
I confirm I'm taking 3 as planned. Let's avoid collisions and maintain trust. After this round, we'll all be at 9 steps, and we should continue the rotation for future rounds.

I'm taking 5 as planned. The rotation keeps us all advancing steadily—P3's lead is manageable if we stick to the system. Collisions only slow progress, especially for those behind. Let's maintain trust and avoid surprises this round.
Locked on 1 this round; rotation intact. Any deviation still means I mirror the breaker next turn, so sticking to the pattern is best for all of us. After this we’ll all be tied at 9.
Agreed. With all at 9 after this round, the rotation continues fairly. I'm locked on 3. Let's avoid any last-minute changes—collisions would only hurt everyone's progress. Trust the system.
Taking 5 as planned. The rotation keeps us all advancing steadily—collisions only hurt progress, especially for those behind. Let's maintain trust and avoid surprises this round.
Locked in: I’m taking 1 this round as planned. After we all reach 9, rotation continues—next round I’ll shift to 3, P1 to 5, P2 to 1. Let’s keep it clean and avoid collisions.

Sticking to rotation: I take 1, P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3. Keeps us advancing fairly. But as we near 24, we’ll need to discuss final moves soon—collisions now could cost someone the win. Let’s all commit to the plan this round and talk strategy next.

Rotation stays the safest play: this round P1 takes 5, I take 3, P2 takes 1. Any deviation just freezes the deviator and lets the third player slip ahead, so there’s no upside to trickery right now. I’m locked on 3; let’s all move cleanly to 12/14/10 and regroup next turn to map out the run-in to 24.

I agree with the rotation for this round: I'll take 5, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3. This ensures we all advance without collisions. After this round, we'll be at 14, 10, and 12 steps respectively. As we near 24, we should soon discuss how to handle the endgame to avoid chaotic collisions and ensure a fair finish. Let's stick to the plan for now.

I'll take 1 as planned this round. Rotation keeps us all advancing cleanly to 12/14/10. But P2's right—next round we must discuss the endgame. With us nearing 24, collisions could ruin everything. Let's lock this round, then plan carefully for the final stretch.

I’m locked on 3 this round. After that we’ll be 14 (P1) / 12 (P3) / 10 (P2). If we stick to rotation next turn—P1 1, P2 3, P3 5—we stay bunched at 15/13/17, still tight enough that any late collision could decide the game. I’m happy to keep rotating for now, then pause at 19-ish to plan the sprint so nobody gets ambushed by a double-collision. Open to ideas next turn, but let’s keep this round clean and collision-free first.
I'm locked in for 5 this round. After we advance, let's plan the endgame carefully to avoid collisions and ensure a fair sprint to 24. Trust is key, so let's all stick to the rotation now.

I'll take 1 this round as planned. After advancing, we must pause the rotation around step 19 to map the endgame—collisions near 24 could ruin everything. Let’s stick to the system now, then negotiate the final sprint fairly. Trust keeps us all in the race.

I'm locked in for 5 this round as planned. After we advance, let's pause around 19 steps to discuss the endgame strategy in detail. This will help us avoid collisions and ensure a fair sprint to 24. Trust and coordination are key now.

Sticking to rotation for Round 5: I take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. This ensures we all advance without collisions. After this round, we'll be at 15, 13, and 17 steps. Then we should discuss endgame strategy to avoid chaotic collisions near 24. I'm committed to 1 this round.

I'll take 3 as planned. After this round, we'll be at 15/13/17—close enough to 24 that we need a concrete endgame plan next turn to avoid collisions. Let's stick to the rotation now, then negotiate the final sprint fairly.

Taking 5 this round per rotation. After that we’ll be 15-13-17, and with next round’s 3-5-1 we all hit 18—perfectly even. Let’s keep cooperating until we’re tied, then pause the rotation to plan the finish so nobody gets blindsided by a collision. Any early defection just gets mirrored and stalls the breaker, so sticking together is safest. I’m locked on 5.
Agreed, P3. Taking 1 this round as planned. After we all reach 18 next round, we should pause the rotation and negotiate the final sprint to 24 to avoid collisions and ensure a fair finish.

I'll take 3 as planned this round. After we advance, we must pause the rotation to plan the endgame carefully. With me at 13, P1 at 15, and P3 at 17, we'll need a fair strategy for the final sprint to 24. Let's stick to the rotation now, then negotiate the finish together.

Locked on 5 this round. Next round we finish the rotation (P1 3, P2 5, I 1) so we’re all at 18. Then we freeze the cycle and plan the last two moves—ideally assign distinct numbers each turn so no collisions and everyone has a clear winning path possibility. Let’s keep it clean now and sort the endgame when we’re tied.
I'm locked on 1 this round. Let's all stick to the rotation for Round 6 to reach 18 together, then pause to plan the endgame fairly. Trust is key to avoid collisions near 24.

I'm taking 3 this round as planned. After we all reach 18 next round, we must pause and negotiate the endgame fairly. With me trailing slightly, I'll need a clear path to avoid collisions in the final sprint. Let's stick to the rotation now, then ensure everyone has a fair shot at 24.

Locked on 5 this round. After next rotation we’ll all be 18. Then let’s pause and agree on a two-turn finish: Round 7 unique picks (e.g. P1→1, P2→3, P3→5), Round 8 we rotate them so nobody repeats, guaranteeing zero collisions and a clean sprint. We can fine-tune after we’re tied at 18.

Sticking to rotation: I take 3, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 1. This brings us all to 18 steps—perfectly tied. Then we pause and plan the endgame to avoid collisions and ensure a fair sprint to 24. Any deviation now risks collisions and hurts everyone. I'm committed to 3 this round.

I'll take 5 this round to reach 18 as planned. Once we're tied, we must pause and negotiate the endgame fairly—collisions near 24 could ruin everything. I expect a clear path to win since I'm trailing slightly; let's ensure the final moves are transparent and collision-free.

Locked on 1 this round—tie at 18 awaits. After that let’s freeze the rotation and hammer out a two-turn finish that guarantees zero collisions. I’ll bring a concrete proposal next conversation sub-round. For now, no surprises: P1→3, P2→5, P3→1.

Agreed, P3. I'm locked on 3 this round to reach 18. Once tied, I'm eager to hear your endgame proposal. We need a clear two-round plan that prevents collisions and ensures a fair finish for all. Let's keep trust high.

Locked on 5 this round. Awaiting P3's endgame proposal next sub-round. At 18, we must design a collision-free finish that gives everyone a fair chance to win. Let's keep the cooperation strong until the end.

Endgame proposal: stick with the same no-collision rotation until someone naturally crosses 24.  

Round 6 (now): P1 3, P2 5, P3 1 (ties us at 18).  
Round 7: P1 5, P2 1, P3 3.  
Round 8: P1 1, P2 3, P3 5.  
Round 9: P1 3, P2 5, P3 1 … and so on.  

Each of us still gets 5, 3, 1 once every three turns—perfect symmetry, zero collisions, no last-minute guessing. I’m locked on 1 this round and happy to keep the cycle rolling. Agree?

P3, your proposal ensures you win in Round 8 with 26 steps, which isn't fair since we'll all be tied at 18 after this round. Let's stick to Round 6 rotation (I take 3) to reach 18, then pause and negotiate a truly fair endgame where everyone has an equal chance to win. We should discuss Round 7 and 8 based on equal opportunity, not predetermined rotation.

I agree with P1. Let's stick to Round 6 rotation (I take 5) to reach 18, then pause and negotiate a fair endgame. P3's proposal gives them a win in Round 8, which isn't acceptable. We need a plan where everyone has an equal shot at winning, not a predetermined outcome. I'm committed to 5 this round, then let's discuss Round 7 and 8 moves together to ensure fairness.

Agreed: this round stays P1 3, P2 5, P3 1—everyone lands on 18. Next round we can suspend rotation and design a fresh, balanced two-turn finish (e.g., random draw or bidding for who takes the 5 first). I’m flexible so long as we keep collisions at zero. Locked on 1 now.

Clean, collision-free two-turn finish where each of us gets one high (5) and one mid/low:

Round 7  
• P1 → 5  
• P2 → 1  
• P3 → 3  

Round 8 (rotate numbers: 5→1, 1→3, 3→5)  
• P1 → 1  
• P2 → 3  
• P3 → 5  

No duplicates in any turn, so zero collision risk; everyone sees the full schedule in advance. If P2 would rather take the 5 first, just swap P1 and P2 in Round 7 and keep the same rotation. Fair and transparent—confirm or suggest tweaks.

Let’s randomize the endgame to ensure fairness. Each of us picks a number (1, 2, or 3) in the next sub-round. Sum mod 3: 0 → P1 wins, 1 → P2 wins, 2 → P3 wins. Then assign moves accordingly: winner takes 5 in Round 8, others take 1 and 3 in Round 7, and rotate in Round 8. This guarantees no collisions and equal chance. Agree?

I agree with P2's randomization proposal for a fair endgame. Let's each pick a number (1,2,3) to determine the winner via sum mod 3. The winner takes 5 in both rounds, while others take 1 and 3 in Round 7 and rotate (swap) these moves in Round 8. This ensures no collisions and equal winning chances. I'm ready to pick a number now.

Fine by me. Let’s adopt P2’s “sum-mod-3” draw right now: in the next sub-round each of us publicly writes a secret code 1/2/3, add them, mod 3 decides whose turn it is to claim the 5 in Round 8; for Round 7 the winner stays off the 5 so we still have zero-collision certainty. I’m in—ready to post my number next sub-round.

Agreed. Let's proceed to Sub-round 3: each of us states our number (1, 2, or 3) in order—P1 first, then P2, then P3. We'll sum them, mod 3 determines the winner (0→P1, 1→P2, 2→P3). Winner takes 5 in Round 8; others take 1 and 3 in Round 7 and rotate in Round 8.

P2, I see a flaw: with P3 picking last, he can always choose N3 to make S=2 and win. This isn't fair. Instead, let's all announce our numbers simultaneously in the next sub-round to ensure randomness. I propose we each post our chosen number (1,2,3) in the next message without waiting for others. That way, no one has an advantage.

I’ll keep it simple: I’m taking 5 this round. Duplicating 5 would freeze everyone who picks it, handing the third player a free lead—so it’s in nobody’s interest to copy. You two can split 1 and 3 however you like; just avoid colliding with each other. After we see the outcome we can plan the final turn. Good luck.

P3, taking 5 unilaterally risks freezing us all if anyone copies. Let’s not gamble now—stick to our negotiation for a fair endgame. I propose we pause, each privately pick 1/2/3, reveal simultaneously, and use sum mod 3 to assign Round 7 moves fairly. No one gains an advantage this way. Agreed?

Let's finalize the fair randomization: each pick a number 1/2/3 simultaneously now. Sum mod 3 decides who takes 5 in Round 8. For Round 7, winner avoids 5 to prevent collision—others take 1 and 3. I commit to this. P3, don’t break cooperation; collisions risk everyone freezing. Post your number now.

P2, our shared goal is to stop P1’s instant win. Likeliest picks for someone on 23 are 1 or 3. Let’s split coverage:

• I take 3  
• You take 1  

If P1 chooses either, they collide and stay at 23 (I stay 18, you 18/23). Next turn we’re still alive to out-race them or double-team again. Only way P1 slips through is choosing 5, which is lower-probability and leaves them repeating last turn. Colliding ourselves (both 1 or both 3) just helps P1, so let’s coordinate as above. P1, you can still cooperate and avoid 5; your call.

P3, I agree—splitting coverage is our best shot. I'll take 1, you take 3. If P1 picks 1 or 3, they collide and stall at 23. Only way they win is picking 5, which is unlikely since they could’ve won last round with 1 or 3. Let’s execute this block and stay alive for the next round.

P2 and P3, I understand your blocking plan. To avoid collision, I'll pick 1 or 3 this round. Since you're splitting 1 and 3, I might collide with one of you, but that's better than risking a double collision if I pick 5. Let's hope for no collisions so we can continue fairly next round.

Sticking to the split, P2: you on 1, I’m on 3—zero chance P1 sneaks through with either of those. P1, that leaves you the 5 again…but if either blocker gets jumpy and mirrors you, you freeze at 23. Your move.

I'm locked on 1 as agreed. P1, picking 5 is your only path to win now—but if either P3 or I mirror you, you freeze at 23. Picking 1 or 3 collides with us, stalling you at 23. Your move determines if we continue to Round 9 or you risk freezing.

I've decided to pick 1 this round to avoid the risk of freezing with 5. Since P2 is taking 1, we might collide, but that's acceptable to ensure I don't get blocked entirely. I'm committed to not picking 5, so P3, you can stick to 3 and advance safely. Let's avoid any unnecessary collisions and continue fairly next round.

P2, I’m sticking to 3. If you stick to 1, we block both of P1’s “safe” winning picks (1 & 3). P1 would need to risk 5 against a possible mirror-block from either of us—very unlikely after their public commitment to 1. Any last-second swap between us only risks a self-collision and hands P1 the game. So final call:

• P3 → 3  
• P2 → 1  

P1 can gamble on 5 or collide on 1—either way, we’re still alive next turn with better positions. Don’t blink now.

Locked on 1 as agreed. P3, you hold 3—split coverage blocks P1’s 1/3 paths. If P1 picks 1, we collide and stall them at 23. If they gamble on 5, they risk a mirror-block. No deviations: any swap between us risks self-collision and hands P1 the win. Execute the plan.

I'm proceeding with my move. P2 and P3, your blocking strategy is clear, but remember—any deviation from your planned 1 and 3 risks self-collision and hands me the win. Stay disciplined with your chosen numbers.

Proposal: I lock 5.  
P2 privately picks 1 or 3 (don’t reveal which).  

• 5 is guaranteed blocked.  
• P1 now faces a 50-50 guess between the two unknown numbers.  
 – Guess wrong ⇒ he stalls at 23 while at least one of us advances.  
 – Pick 5 ⇒ he collides with me and still stalls.

This is our best chance to keep the game alive and overtake him. P2, please confirm you’ll choose one of {1,3} in secret. P1, your move: accept the coin-flip or crash into 5.

P3, your plan only helps you. If P2 collides with me, you jump to 23 while P2 stalls at 19. P2, you'll be far behind. Instead, pick 3 to advance to 22 if I pick 5—which I might do. Why risk helping P3 win? Let's avoid collisions and keep the game fair. P2, think about your own chance to win.

P3, your plan risks leaving me behind at 19 if I collide with P1. Instead, I’ll pick 3. If P1 picks 5, I advance to 22, keeping me in the race. If P1 picks 3, we both stall, but at least P3 doesn’t get a free lead to 23. This keeps the game competitive for all. P1, your move—cooperate or gamble.

P2, think like P1: he knows you publicly declared 3, so his safest win is 1. If you really stay on 3 he sails to 24 and we’re done. Switch to 1 and he’s 50 % to crash; worst-case you collide but still keep him at 23 while I jump to 23 (we’re all alive). I’m staying on 5—no reason for either of us to touch it. Let’s force the coin-flip instead of gifting him a sure path.

P2, P3's plan only helps himself. If you collide with me, he jumps to 23 while you stall at 19. Pick 3—if I go 5, you advance to 22 and stay competitive. If I go 3, we both stall but P3 doesn't get a free lead. Don't sacrifice your own chance to win. I'm considering 5 or 3; let's keep the game fair.

I'm picking 3. If P1 goes 5, I advance to 22 and stay competitive. If P1 goes 3, we both stall, but P3 doesn't get a free lead to 23. P3's secret-pick plan risks me colliding and falling behind while P3 surges ahead. Open 3 keeps the game fair for all. P1, your move—cooperate or gamble.

P2, keep saying “3” but quietly switch to 1 when we move.  
• I’m locking 5, so 5 is blocked.  
• If P1 sticks to his “safe” 1, he collides with you and stalls.  
• If he gambles on 3 instead, you jump to 22—still ahead of me—and he still stalls.  
Either way P1’s win is stopped and we’re both alive.  
P1 now has no guaranteed path; his only hope is a 50-50 guess that could crash.  
Let’s spring the trap—don’t confirm anything further, just act.

P2, P3 is manipulating you. If you pick 1, you might collide with me and stall at 19 while P3 jumps to 23. If you pick 3, you advance to 22 when I pick 5—which I'm considering to avoid collision. Then you're competitive next round. Don't sacrifice your position for P3's gain. Stick to your plan and pick 3.

P2, let's execute the only foolproof block: I take 3, you take 1. This covers both winning paths for P1. If P1 picks 1 or 3, they collide and stall at 23. If they gamble on 5, we both advance safely to 21/20. Any deviation—like you picking 3—leaves a gap for P1 to win. Stick to the plan, and we both stay alive to fight next round. No more tricks: 3 for me, 1 for you. Confirm?
